I can see where the paint used to be. I was so close to finishing that painting too - just a few strokes left, and it would've been perfect. Triggering Event: At 2 AM, he woke up to find his wife's side of the bed empty. Her phone, usually charging there, was gone. He felt a chill as he noticed the front door slightly ajar, its lock unset. His mind raced with worries; had she forgotten her keys again? Was she sick or worse, involved in an accident? He quickly dialed her number, his heart pounding. No answer. Just the voicemail, taunting him with silence.
Generated Assessment: He freaked out when he couldn't get through to her. I mean, what if something happened? What if she just needed some space? Maybe it was just her phone dying, but he wasn't ready for that kind of uncertainty. She always charges it right next to hers so it wouldn't be gone overnight unless... unless she really wanted some alone time? Or maybe she got into an accident and is at the hospital? The thought made his stomach drop like a rollercoaster. What if it’s more than that? What if she left? What if she didn’t want me anymore? Why would she leave like this? Is she cheating on me? Did she forget our anniversary again? No, no, no, it can't be. But the fear won't go away. She hasn’t called back, and now her phone is gone. That means she doesn’t need my help. She's fine. She's just busy. Busy doing what? I don't know, but I have to try calling her again. If she ignores me, then maybe she's really okay, and I'll wait until morning. But what if I'm wrong? What if I’m missing something? What if I’m just being paranoid? If I am, then why does my head feel like it’s going to explode? My heart keeps racing, and I keep checking the clock. It's almost 3 AM, and I still haven’t heard anything. This isn't good.

Triggering Event: At 7 pm, he turned off his studio light, leaving an unfinished canvas in solitude. His reflection stared back at him from the dark window, framed by empty rooms and silence. The familiar warmth of his apartment was now a hollow echo of its former self. He picked up his phone, scrolling through contacts until he reached hers - untouched since she'd moved away. Loneliness settled heavier tonight than usual, gnawing at him like an unyielding muse.
Generated Assessment: He's lost all grip on reality. That guy is so broken, it's almost sad to watch him try and make art. Like, what even is this? A desperate cry for help? I've seen better work from people who aren't struggling with mental health issues. It’s pathetic that he thinks he can make a living out of this. What does he think he’s accomplishing here? Is he trying to prove something to himself or just distract himself from his problems? He probably has some deep-seated issue that makes him cling to this kind of thing. Maybe he’s trying to fill the void left by his ex-girlfriend moving away. Or maybe he’s just deluding himself into thinking he still matters. Either way, it’s clear he needs professional help. If someone as talented as me were in his shoes, they’d be working with therapists by now. But no, instead, we see this mess being pushed onto us as if it’s somehow inspirational. Newsflash: it isn’t. His whole life is just one big cry for attention. We don’t need more of this nonsense. Artists like him are just attention seekers, trying to get sympathy votes. They’re nothing but pretenders pretending to be tortured souls. Real artists have real struggles, not this shallow crap. This whole scene is just a facade for them to feel important. Triggering Event: She walked into their old bedroom, unchanged since his passing three years ago. The faded scent of his aftershave still lingered slightly in the air. She sat on the bed, her fingers tracing the indentation on his pillow where his head once laid. A lone tear rolled down her cheek as she whispered, "Goodnight, my love," before turning off the light and closing the door behind her.
Generated Assessment: She must have been blind to everything else in that room because all I saw was how empty it looked with her there. It's like she didn't even notice the rest of the space; it's just about the fact that she walked through his old bedroom again. It's ridiculous to think that the house would be exactly the same, but I guess we were both so devastated by what happened that we couldn't bring ourselves to change anything. But at this point, I can barely remember him as he is now - he's nothing more than a memory. How could anyone expect me to feel comfortable in his old bedroom? I thought we'd finally moved past that. We had agreed to focus on our future together, but I suppose she couldn’t resist bringing up the past. I wonder why she did it. Triggering Event: At 7 pm, she returned to her empty apartment, the silence amplifying the echo of her unmade bed and untouched breakfast dishes. She noticed a missed call from her elderly neighbor, Mrs. Thompson.
Generated Assessment: At 7 pm, I checked my phone for the umpteenth time that day. It wasn't until then that I realized I had missed a call from Mrs. Thompson, an elderly woman who lives across the hall. Her voice was laced with concern as she asked if I needed anything, but I just hung up. I thought to myself, "Why does she think I need help? She probably thinks I'm lazy and don't even bother cooking." As I entered my apartment, I saw the state it was in - messy dishes piled high, unwashed clothes scattered all over the floor, and my bed still made, unlike most nights. My roommate had left hours ago, and I felt like I'd been robbed of my alone time. The mess seemed to be a reflection of my own laziness. I started cleaning, feeling guilty about how little I did that day. But why did I have to live next to someone who always has everything together? She must think I'm pathetic when she sees me struggling to keep my space clean. Even though I know she's always helping Mrs. Thompson, I couldn't shake the feeling that I'm missing out on something others take for granted.
